references: Proposing new LDP mechanisms. Based on results ofÂ [8], TableÂ I on PageÂ I shows that among the three mechanisms Duchi, Laplace, and PM, in terms of the worst-case variance, Duchi is the best for 0<Ïµ<1.290italic-Ïµ1.290<\epsilon<1.29, while PM is the best for Ïµ>1.29italic-Ïµ1.29\epsilon>1.29. Then a natural research question is that can we propose better or even optimal LDP mechanisms? The optimal LDP mechanism for numeric data is still open in the literature, but the optimal LDP mechanism for categorical data has been discussed by KairouzÂ etÂ al.Â [12]. In particular,Â [12] shows that for a categorical attribute (with a limited number of discrete values), the binary and randomized response mechanisms, are universally optimal for very small and large Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, respectively. AlthoughÂ [12] handles categorical data, its results can provide the following insight even for continuous numeric data: for very small Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, a mechanism generating a binary output should be optimal; for very large Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, the optimal mechanismâ€™s output should have infinite possibilities. This is also in consistent with the results of TableÂ I on PageÂ I. Based on the above insight, intuitively, there may exist a range of medium Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon where a mechanism with three, or four, or five, â€¦ output possibilities can be optimal. To this end, our first motivation of proposing new LDP mechanisms is to develop a mechanism with three output possibilities such that the mechanism outperform existing mechanisms of TableÂ I for some Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. The outcome of the above motivation is our mechanism called Three-Outputs. Since the analysis of Three-Outputs is already very complex, we do not consider a mechanism with four, or five, â€¦ output possibilities.

TableÂ II on PageÂ II gives a comparison of our and existing LDP mechanisms. For simplicity, we do not include Laplace in the comparison since Laplace is worse than PM for any Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon according to TableÂ I. As shown in TableÂ II, in terms of the worst-case variance for a single numeric attribute with a domain [âˆ’1,1]11[-1,1], Three-Outputs outperforms Duchi for Ïµ>lnâ¡2â‰ˆ0.69italic-Ïµ20.69\epsilon>\ln 2\approx 0.69 (and is the same as Duchi for Ïµâ‰¤lnâ¡2italic-Ïµ2\epsilon\leq\ln 2), while PM-SUB beats PM for any Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon; moreover, Three-Outputs outperforms both Duchi and PM for lnâ¡2<Ïµ<3.272italic-Ïµ3.27\ln 2<\epsilon<3.27, while PM-SUB beats both Duchi and PM for Ïµ>1.19italic-Ïµ1.19\epsilon>1.19.

references: TableÂ II on PageÂ II gives a comparison of our and existing LDP mechanisms. For simplicity, we do not include Laplace in the comparison since Laplace is worse than PM for any Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon according to TableÂ I. As shown in TableÂ II, in terms of the worst-case variance for a single numeric attribute with a domain [âˆ’1,1]11[-1,1], Three-Outputs outperforms Duchi for Ïµ>lnâ¡2â‰ˆ0.69italic-Ïµ20.69\epsilon>\ln 2\approx 0.69 (and is the same as Duchi for Ïµâ‰¤lnâ¡2italic-Ïµ2\epsilon\leq\ln 2), while PM-SUB beats PM for any Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon; moreover, Three-Outputs outperforms both Duchi and PM for lnâ¡2<Ïµ<3.272italic-Ïµ3.27\ln 2<\epsilon<3.27, while PM-SUB beats both Duchi and PM for Ïµ>1.19italic-Ïµ1.19\epsilon>1.19.

Using the LDP-FedSGD algorithm for federated learning in IoV as a motivating context, we present novel LDP mechanisms for numeric data with a continuous domain. Among our proposed mechanisms, Three-Outputs and PM-SUB outperform existing mechanisms for a wide range of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, as shown in the theoretical results in TableÂ II and confirmed by experiments. In terms of comparing our Three-Outputs and PM-SUB, we have: Three-Outputs, whose output has three possibilities, is better for small Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, while PM-SUB, whose output can take infinite possibilities of an interval, has higher utility for large Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Our PM-SUB is a slightly suboptimal version of our PM-OPT to simplify the expressions. We further combine Three-Outputs and PM-SUB to obtain a hybrid mechanism HM-TP, which achieves even higher utility.

S3.T3.caption: TABLE III: We compare different privacy notions in this table. In this paper, we focus on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-local differential privacy which achieves user-level privacy protection with distributed perturbation (ULDP). We do not consider record-level privacy protection with distributed perturbation (RLDP) which implements perturbation at each user via standard differential privacy, since we aim to achieve user-level privacy protection instead of the weaker record-level privacy protection (a vehicle is a user in our IoV applications and may have multiple records). We also do not investigate record/user-level privacy protection with centralized perturbation (RLCP/ULCP) since this paper considers a honest-but-curious aggregator instead of a trusted aggregator.

In the case of distributed perturbation, when all users set the same privacy parameter Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, we refer to ULDP and RLDP above as Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-ULDP and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-RLDP, respectively. TableÂ III presents a comparison of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-ULDP, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-RLDP, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-RLCP, and
Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-ULCP. In this paperâ€™s focus, each user applies Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-local differential privacy, so our framework is under ULDP. The reasons that we consider ULDP instead of RLDP, RLCP, and ULCP are as follows.
